elements.name: deceasedIntroExplanation
elements.title: First, this service will ask about the person who died. Details about their life will affect later questions. That is why this service will ask about you, the `applicant(s)`, in a later step.

elements.name: deceasedName
elements.title: What is the name of the person who died?
elements.description:
If {deceasedName} made a `Will`, you should use the exact spelling of their name on their Will.

If {deceasedName} did not make a Will, you should use the exact spelling of their name on their government-issued photo ID.

elements.name: deceasedNameFAQ1
elements.title: What if the {deceasedName} used more than one spelling or version of their name?
elements.body: This service will ask you for other spellings and versions of {deceasedName}'s name in a later step.

elements.name: deceasedNameFAQ2
elements.title: What if {deceasedName}'s name is originally in a different language?
elements.body: You will need a version of {deceasedName}'s name that is written using the Roman alphabet. English and French are examples of languages that use the Roman alphabet.

elements.name: jiraRepgrant28
elements.title: JIRA ticket REPGRANT-28 - Name Capitalization based on Input Device

elements.name: deceasedNameReplace
elements.title:
This service will ask a lot of questions using the full name of the person who died: "{deceasedName}".

Would you like this service to show you a more familiar name instead?
elements.description: This familiar name is only used to personalize your experience with this service. It will not appear on the actual `Representation Grant`.

elements.name: deceasedNickname
elements.title: What name would you like to see instead of "{deceasedName}"?
elements.description:
You can choose any name you like. For example, "your husband" or "Uncle Jesse" or "Cousin Stavros".

You can always come back to change this name at any time.

elements.name: jiraRepgrant29
elements.title: JIRA ticket REPGRANT-29 - Deceased Nickname Substitution

elements.name: deceasedDateOfDeath
elements.title: When did {deceasedName} die?
elements.description: If you are unsure, this date can be found on {deceasedName}'s `Certificate of Death`.

elements.name: deceasedDateOfDeathFAQ1
elements.title: How do I get a `Certificate of Death`
elements.body:
A `Certificate of Death` comes from the place where {deceasedName} died.

If {deceasedName} died in British Columbia, their Certificate of Death comes from the Vital Statistics Agency of British Columbia. You can get a Certificate of Death directly from Vital Statistics or you can ask a funeral home to get a Certificate of Death for you.

Click here for more information from the Government of British Columbia's website. (This link opens in a new tab)

If {deceasedName} died outside of British Columbia but still inside of Canada, you must get a Certificate of Death from the province or territory where they died.

Click here for other Vital Statistics Agencies in Canada. (This link opens in a new tab)

If {deceasedName} died outside of Canada, you must get a Certificate of Death from the state or country where they died.

elements.name: question412
elements.title:
A `Certificate of Death` comes from the place where {deceasedName} died.

If {deceasedName} died in British Columbia, their Certificate of Death comes from the Vital Statistics Agency of British Columbia. You can get a Certificate of Death directly from Vital Statistics or you can ask a funeral home to get a Certificate of Death for you.

Click here for more information from the Government of British Columbia's website. (This link opens in a new tab)

If {deceasedName} died outside of British Columbia but still inside of Canada, you must get a Certificate of Death from the province or territory where they died.

Click here for other Vital Statistics Agencies in Canada. (This link opens in a new tab)

If {deceasedName} died outside of Canada, you must get a Certificate of Death from the state or country where they died.

elements.name: deceasedAddress
elements.title: What was {deceasedName}'s last known address?
elements.description:
If {deceasedName} was homeless:
  • write "no fixed address" for the street address
  • Write the city/town, province and country where they lived.
  • Write "n/a" for their postal code.

elements.name: deceasedAddressFAQ1
elements.title: [obsolete unless the description version is too cumbersom/bulky] What if {deceasedName} was homeless?
elements.body:
If {deceasedName} was homeless, write "no fixed address" for the street number and street name. 

Write the city/town, province and country where they lived.

Write "n/a" for their postal code.

elements.name: deceasedAddressFAQ2
elements.title:
[Obsolete?] 
What if {deceasedName} spent equal time in more than one place? [Add lawyer info]
elements.body:
If {deceased} spent equal in more than one place, choose the place where they had most of their financial and social connections.

If you're still not sure which address you should choose, you may want to talk to a lawyer.

Click here to get lawyer info if you need to find one.

elements.name: question438
elements.title:
[Location triggered Explanation Obsolete here?? - Will questions determine which asset affidavit to use regardless of where the address is]

This service can help you extend the powers of a `Representation Grant` from another place.

It makes sense to first get a `Representation Grant` from where {deceasedName} spent most of their time. There may be benefits to getting grants in this order that a lawyer can explain to you. [link to lawyer info]

If you don't already have a Representation Grant from the place where {deceasedName} spent most of their time, this service can still help you apply for a B.C. Representation Grant.

elements.name: willIntroExplanation
elements.title:
This step in the service will ask if {deceasedName} made a `Will` or any `other testamentary documents`.

If {deceasedName} made a Will, there will be a lot of questions about the Will. These questions help prove to the Court that {deceasedName}'s Will represents how {deceasedName} wants their belongings managed.

elements.name: willPreviousWillCheckBookmark
elements.title: Previous Will Check

elements.name: willCheck
elements.title: Have you looked for {deceasedName}'s `Will`
elements.description:
This means checking all the places where {deceasedName} kept important documents.

Physical places include their home, safety deposit box, and their lawyer's office.

Electronic places include their smart phone, computer, external hard drive, and cloud storage.

elements.name: willCheckFAQ1
elements.title: Do I have look for {deceasedName}'s `Will` all by myself?
elements.body:
The person applying for a `Representation Grant` has to look for {deceasedName}'s `Will`.

If several people are applying together for a `Representation Grant`, you can decide which `applicant` looks where.

elements.name: question439
elements.title:
[Delete later]
The person applying for a `Representation Grant` has to look for {deceasedName}'s `Will`.

If several people are applying together for a `Representation Grant`, you can decide which `applicant` looks where.

elements.name: willCheckFAQ2
elements.title: Do I have to get a "Search of Wills Notice" right now?
elements.body:
A "Search of Wills Notice" is a document from the Vital Statistics Agency of British Columbia that can tell you where to find a `Will`.

You will need a "Search of Wills Notice" as part of your `Representation Grant` `application`. You can get a "Search of Wills Notice" on your own at anytime, or you can wait for this service to help you get this document in a later step.

The reason this service helps you with a "Search of Wills Notice" in a later step is because it needs to include all of the different names and spellings that {deceasedName} used in their Will and for their `assets`.

If you believe {deceasedName} made a `Will` and you feel you need help finding it now, you may consider getting a "Search of Wills Notice" right now. If you get this document on your own, this service will check that it was done correctly.

If you want to get a "Search of Wills Notice" right now, click here to download a blank form. (This link opens in a new tab)

Electronic places include their smart phone, computer, external hard drive, and cloud storage.

If you believe {deceasedName} made a `Will` and you feel you need help finding it, click "Do I need to get a "Search of Wills Notice" right now?". (This can be found right above)

elements.name: willGrantExistsBookmark
elements.title: Grant Already Exists

elements.name: willGrantExistsIntro
elements.title:
Next, we need to figure out if a `Representation Grant` for {deceasedName} already exists.

If a Representation Grant for {deceased} already exists, this service will ask different questions to complete your `applicant`.

elements.name: willGrantExists
elements.title: Does a `Representation Grant` for {deceasedName} already exist?

elements.name: willGrantExistsFAQ1
elements.title: What if I believe a `Representation Grant` for {deceasedName} already exists but I/we cannot find it?
elements.body:
If you believe a `Representation Grant` for {deceasedName} already exists, this service cannot help you apply for a `Representation Grant` at this point in time.

For now, this service has only been developed for a limited number of situations. Select "Yes" for the question above to see the next steps that you can take. You will need to take these steps on your own without this service.

elements.name: willGrantExistsNoErrorCurrent
elements.title:
For now, this service has only been developed for a limited number of situations. At this point in time, this service cannot help you apply for a `Representation Grant`.

If the existing Representation Grant is from British Columbia, and you need to add a new person onto the Representation Grant, please talk to a lawyer. This is not a simple matter.

If the existing Representation Grant is from British Columbia, and you have more `assets` to report, stop using this service. Use either form P14 or P15 to tell the court. Forms P14 and P15 can be found here. (This link opens in a new tab)

If the existing Representation Grant is from a British Commonwealth country, the United States of America or Hong Kong, the existing Representation Grant can be resealed. Please refer to the Supreme Court Civil Rules under Rule 25-6 - Application for Resealing for information on resealing the Representation Grant. (This link opens in a new tab)

If the existing Representation Grant is not from a British Commonwealth country, the United States of America or Hong Kong, you will have to apply for an ancillary Representation Grant. The forms to apply for an ancillary grant can be found here. (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: willGrantBC
elements.title: Was this Representation Grant issued in British Columbia?

elements.name: willGrantExistsNoErrorFuture
elements.title:
[Nov 5 2020 - copied from qualify page]
[Feb 2 2021 - chop up for future when different scenarios are available for beta via product manager]
For now, this service has only been developed for a limited number of situations. At this point in time, this service cannot help you apply for a Representation Grant.

If the existing Representation Grant is from British Columbia, and you need to add a new person onto the existing Representation Grant, please seek help from a lawyer. This is not a simple matter.

If the existing Representation Grant is from British Columbia, and you have more assets to report, do not apply for another Representation Grant. Use either form P14 or P15 to tell the court.

If the grant is from a British Commonwealth country, the United States of America or Hong Kong, you will have to reseal the original grant. Please refer to the Supreme Court Civil Rules under Rule 25-6 - Application for Resealing for information on resealing your grant.

If the grant is not from a British Commonwealth country, the United States of America or Hong Kong, you will have to apply for an ancillary grant. The forms to apply for an ancillary grant can be found here.

elements.name: willExists
elements.title: Did {deceasedName} make a `Will`

elements.name: willExistsFAQ1
elements.title: What if I believe {deceasedName} made a `Will` but I/we cannot find it?
elements.body:
If you cannot find {deceasedName}'s `Will`, you can keep looking for it or you can decide to apply for a `Representation Grant` as if {deceasedName} did not make a Will.

If you decide to keep looking for {deceasedName}'s Will, only select "Yes" to this question when you find their Will.

If you decide to apply for a `Representation Grant` as if {deceasedName} did not make a Will, Select "No" to this question.
  • If you find {deceasedName}'s Will before you finish applying for your Representation Grant, come back to this question and change the answer/selection to "Yes".
  • If you find {deceasedName}'s Will after you already got your Representation Grant, you can apply for a new Representation Grant using their Will to replace the old one.

elements.name: question411
elements.title:

If you decide to apply for a `Representation Grant` as if {deceasedName} did not make a Will, Select "No" to this question.
  • If you find {deceasedName}'s Will before you finish applying for your Representation Grant, come back to this question and change the answer/selection to "Yes".
  • If you find {deceasedName}'s Will after you already got your Representation Grant, you can apply for a new Representation Grant using their Will to replace the old one.

elements.body:
If you don't know if {deceasedName}'s `Will` is valid or not, select "Yes". This service will ask questions to check if the Will is valid.

If necessary, this service may ask if {deceasedName} made more than one Will.

elements.body:
No. This question is only about the Will.

If {deceasedName} made a `codicil` or `other testamentary documents`, this service will ask about those documents later.

elements.name: willRevoked
elements.title: Did {deceasedName}'s latest Will replace their older Wills?
elements.description: Look at the will. Usually at the beginning. "This is the last will and revokes/replaces all previous wills" or similar wording.

elements.name: willRevokedYesExplanation
elements.title:
If {deceasedName} made a new Will that replaced an older one, answer the following questions using information from the most recent Will. If their most recent Will is valid, you will not need to answer questions about old Wills.

If {deceasedName}'s most recent Will has any issues, this service may ask about their next most recent Will.

elements.name: willDifferentAssetsNoExplanation
elements.title:
[No - Super Rare]
Start by answering the following questions with information from {deceasedName}'s most recent Will first. This service will have questions about the older Wills separately. [Trigger a series of questions: Ask questions about the existence of the older one(s)? 1. Date made. 2. Alias. Nothing else. 3. Does this revoke a previous will? ifNo. 4. Is there a previous will?
reminders to make copies as well.] [In the other successors page, ask if prior wills list any other executors, beneficiaries etc].

elements.title: Did you want to administer more than one of {deceasedName}'s Wills?

elements.name: willAdministerMultipleNoExplanation
elements.title:
[No]
Answer the following questions using information from the Will that deals with the assets that you wish to administer. [??revisit with consistent language].

elements.title:
[Yes]
If {deceasedName} made more than one Will that each deal with different property/assets, you will have to apply for more than one Representation Grant, for each will.

elements.title: yes to signature on rando page; no explanation. will is likely to get accepted but may only be recognized up the page it is signed. well ask more questions. - ask if they want to do sec80 first.

elements.name: question210
elements.title:
yes signature on rando page; yes to some hand written (or typed?) explanation anywhere
generally, documents need to be signed at the end but because there is an explanation, it might be get accepted by court. there may be restrictions on what part of the will is recognized.
you may want to do sec 80. It will require affidavits. If you already have some, no extra cost. If you need someone to swear/affirm an affidavit, may cost up $40 per affidavit.

elements.name: question211
elements.title: do you want to do sec 80 now? (may cost up to $40 to swear affidavits) vs hoping no one disputes the will. can do 58 later

elements.name: question215
elements.title:
yes to sig on rando page; yes to some hand written (or typed?) explanation anywhere
[do we need a duplicate for yes explanation or no explanation?]
generally, documents need to be signed at the end but because there is an explanation, it might be get accepted by court. there may be restrictions on what part of the will is recognized. If you are concerned, you can do an extra form (P42 sec58) to have the whole thing recognized.

you can do a sec58 later as well if any problems arise. (with 180 days of getting the grant). will cost $80.

elements.name: question216
elements.title: do you want to do a sec 58 now? ($80) vs hoping no one disputes the will. can do 58 later

elements.name: question167
elements.title:
[not signed at all]
This document is unlikely to be recognized as a will.
[distinction for future between multiple wills and single will]
has to be some indication that deceased knew and approved the contents of the document for it be accepted as a will. this is expressed by a signature. it is unlikely that an unsigned doc will be recognized as a will in BC. if you believe there are exceptional circumstances that provide evidence that the deceased knew and approved the contents of the will, you may wish to seek a lawyer to get advice. you can proceed as if this will did not exist (if the outcome for where who the assets go to are going to be the same (or can be settled within family/friends without argument). otherwise we proceed with questions, which will require affidavits explaining the will is not signed but should be recognized as a will. this may cost money in affadavit and/or application fees.

elements.name: willP5NoWillNoOtherDocExplanation
elements.title:
Because {deceasedName} did not make a `Will` or any `other testamentary document`, you can move on to the next step.

The next step is to identify the people in {deceasedName}'s life who need to know that you are applying for a `Representation Grant`. This service will start by asking if {deceasedName} had a spouse or any children.

elements.name: willP5NoWillYesOtherDocNoRecExplanation
elements.title:
Moving forward, this service will help you apply as if {deceasedName} did not make a `Will` because you've indicated that:

  • {deceasedName} didn't make a valid Will,
  • {deceasedName} did make one or more `osther testamentary document` but you don't believe any of them should be recognized as {deceasedName}'s Will

You will need to provide a copy of the other testamentary document(s) in your application. This service will remind you to make a copy at the end.

The next step is to identify the people in {deceasedName}'s life who need to know that you are applying for a `Representation Grant`. This service will start by asking if {deceasedName} had a spouse or any children.

this service will help you apply as if {deceasedName} did not make a Will.

elements.name: question187
elements.title:
Part 1: ORDER(S) SOUGHT

The petitioner(s) seek(s) the following order under section 58 (2) (a) of the Wills, Estates and Succession Act:

[indent] 1 that the attached record, document or writing represents the testamentary intentions of a deceased person

elements.name: question188
elements.title:
Part 2: FACTUAL BASIS

[Using numbered paragraphs, set out the material facts on which this petition is based.]
1
2

elements.name: question189
elements.title:
What are the facts?
(you/someone else will need support these facts with evidence such affidavits or other documents)
elements.description:
[Description]The key question is whether the document records a deliberate or fixed and final expression of intention as to the disposal of the deceased’s property on death. A deliberate or fixed and final intention is not the equivalent of an irrevocable intention, given that a will, by its nature, is revocable until the death of its maker. Rather, the intention must be fixed and final at the material time, which will vary depending on the circumstances.

[Reference: https://www.canlii.org/en/bc/bcsc/doc/2019/2019bcsc2040/2019bcsc2040.html?searchUrlHash=AAAAAQAoc2VjdGlvbiA1OCB3aWxscywgZXN0YXRlcyBhbmQgc3VjY2Vzc2lvbgAAAAAB&resultIndex=5]

elements.name: question190
elements.title:
Part 3: LEGAL BASIS
[Using numbered paragraphs, specify any rule or other enactment relied on and provide a brief summary of any other legal bases on which the petitioner(s) intend(s) to rely in support of the orders sought.] Para1 1 Section 58 of WESA empowers the court to give the relief requested. Court order curing deficiencies 58 (1)In this section, "record" includes data that (a)is recorded or stored electronically, (b)can be read by a person, and (c)is capable of reproduction in a visible form. (2)On application, the court may make an order under subsection (3) if the court determines that a record, document or writing or marking on a will or document represents (a)the testamentary intentions of a deceased person, (b)the intention of a deceased person to revoke, alter or revive a will or testamentary disposition of the deceased person, or (c)the intention of a deceased person to revoke, alter or revive a testamentary disposition contained in a document other than a will. (3)Even though the making, revocation, alteration or revival of a will does not comply with this Act, the court may, as the circumstances require, order that a record or document or writing or marking on a will or document be fully effective as though it had been made (a)as the will or part of the will of the deceased person, (b)as a revocation, alteration or revival of a will of the deceased person, or (c)as the testamentary intention of the deceased person. (4)If an alteration to a will makes a word or provision illegible and the court is satisfied that the alteration was not made in accordance with this Act, the court may reinstate the original word or provision if there is evidence to establish what the original word or provision was.

Move to P9 area?? What if I don't know how to contact someone? It is your responsibility to make sure that everyone who has a right to a part of the deceased's estate is notified. ({executorInfoPanel[0].executorIsAlive} = "y" and {executorInfoPanel[0].executorIsCapable} = "y" and ({executorInfoPanel[0].executorSpecialConditions} = "n" or ({executorInfoPanel[0].executorSpecialConditions} = "y" and {executorInfoPanel[0].executorSpecialConditionsMet} = "y")) and ({executorInfoPanel[0].executorIsExSpouse} = "n" or ({executorInfoPanel[0].executorIsExSpouse} = "y" and {executorInfoPanel[0].executorExSpouseAfterWill} = "y")) and ({executorInfoPanel[0].executorRenounced} = "n" 
or ({executorInfoPanel[0].executorRenounced} = "y" and {executorInfoPanel[0].executorRenouncedFormally} = "n")) and {executorInfoPanel[0].executorRank} notempty)

elements.name: spouseExistsBookmark
elements.title: Spouse Exists

elements.name: spouseExists
elements.title: Did {deceasedName} have a `spouse` when they died?
elements.description: You do not need to include a spouse that {deceasedName} has divorced and has not resumed a marriage-like relationship.

elements.name: spouseExistsFAQ1
elements.title: Do I include someone who was married (with a marriage certificate) to {deceasedName} if they had separated, but not yet divorced?
elements.body:
Yes, you must include someone who {deceasedName} had legally married but had not divorced. This person should know that you are applying for a `Representation Grant`.

You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case the Court decides that this person should be considered {deceasedName}'s `spouse`.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a Representation Grant, they don't automatically get part of {deceasedName}'s `estate`.

For more information, click here to read about who should be included as {deceasedName}'s spouse from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA). (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: spouseExistsFAQ2
elements.title: Do I include someone who was in marriage-like relationship (also know as a common-law marriage) with {deceasedName}, but they broke up before {deceasedName} died?
elements.body:
No, you do not need to include {deceasedName}'s marriage-like partner (also known as a common-law partner) if they broke up.

A marriage-like relationship ends immediately after the break up. {deceasedName}'s ex-partner would not be considered {deceasedName}'s `spouse` anymore.

However, if you are not sure if {deceasedName} and their partner were broken up when {deceasedName} died, it is safer for you to include this person. This person should know that you are applying for a `Representation Grant`.

You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case the Court decides that this person should be considered {deceasedName}'s spouse.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a Representation Grant, they don't automatically get part of {deceasedName}'s `estate`.

For more information, click here to read about who should be included as {deceasedName}'s spouse from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA). (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: spouseExistsFAQ3
elements.title: Do I include someone who was in an on-again, off-again marriage-like relationship with {deceasedName}?
elements.body:
If {deceasedName} lived together with a marriage-like partner (also know as a common-law partner) for at least 2 years, this person would be considered {deceasedName}'s `spouse`.

A marriage-like (common law) relationship ends immediately after the break up. However, under the law in British Columbia, this person could still considered {deceasedName}'s spouse if they broke up and got back together again within a year.

If you are not sure if {deceasedName} and this person had gotten back together before {deceasedName} died, it is safer for you to include this person. This person should know that you are applying for a `Representation Grant`.

You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case the Court decides that this person should be considered {deceasedName}'s spouse.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a Representation Grant, they don't automatically get part of {deceasedName}'s `estate`.

For more information, click here to read about who should be included as {deceasedName}'s spouse from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA). (This link opens in a new tab)

templateElements.name: successorRule25-2(8)
templateElements.title: Rule 25-2 (8) - If person to whom notice is to be delivered is a minor
templateElements.body:
Rule 25-2 (8) - If person to whom notice is to be delivered is a minor
(8) If a person to whom documents are to be delivered under subrule (1) is a minor, the intended applicant must deliver those documents
- (a) as follows:
---   (i) if the applicant knows that the minor resides with all of the minor's parents, to those parents;
---  (ii) if subparagraph (i) does not apply but the applicant knows that a parent or guardian has responsibility for financial decisions relating to the minor, to that parent or guardian;
---   (iii) if neither subparagraph (i) nor subparagraph (ii) applies but the applicant knows of one or more addresses at which the minor resides, to the minor at each of those addresses, and
- (b) subject to subrule (9), to the Public Guardian and Trustee.

templateElements.name: successorRule25-2(9)
templateElements.title: Rule 25-2 (9) - If testamentary trust exists
templateElements.body:
Jack & Tyler (Jul 6 2021) decided to ignore this subrule in favour of service regardless of this situation. The amount of extra programming would likely not be worth the effort considering that a) this subrule doesn't take away that much work from an applicant and b) unnecessary service to minors and their guardians is not likely going to be extra burden.


Rule 25-2 (9) - If testamentary trust exists
(9) An intended applicant need not deliver documents under subrule (8) (b) to the Public Guardian and Trustee if
- (a) the intended applicant is an executor or alternate executor of the deceased's estate,
- (b) the minor is not a spouse or child of the deceased, and
- (c) the deceased's will:
---   (i) creates a trust for the interest of the minor in the estate, and
---   (ii) appoints a trustee for that trust.

templateElements.name: successorRule25-2(10&11)
templateElements.title: Rule 25-2 (10) and (11)
templateElements.body:
If person to whom notice is to be delivered is a mentally incompetent person
(10) Subrule (11) applies if
- (a) there has been appointed for a person to whom documents are to be delivered under subrule (1)
--- (i) a committee appointed under the Patients Property Act, or
--- (ii) the equivalent of a committee appointed by a court outside British Columbia, or
- (b) a person to whom documents are to be delivered under subrule (1) is or may be mentally incompetent and paragraph (a) of this subrule does not apply to the person.

How notice may be delivered to a mentally incompetent person
(11) If subrule (10) applies to a person to whom documents are to be delivered under subrule (1), the intended applicant must deliver the documents to the person as follows:
- (a) if subrule (10) (a) (i) applies, by delivering the documents to
--- (i) the committee referred to in that subparagraph, and
--- (ii) the Public Guardian and Trustee;
- (b) if subrule (10) (a) (ii) applies, by delivering the documents to
--- (i) the equivalent person referred to in that subparagraph, and
--- (ii) the Public Guardian and Trustee;
- (c) if subrule (10) (b) applies, by delivering the documents to the Public Guardian and Trustee in addition to delivering those documents to the person.

templateElements.name: spouseNomineeFormal
templateElements.title: Was {panel.spouseNomineeName} formally appointed to help {panel.spouseName} manage their money and legal decisions?
templateElements.description:
These are the ways someone can be formally appointed.
  • {panel.spouseName} could have signed a document that gave someone else the power of attorney using the Power of Attorney Act,
  • {panel.spouseName} could have signed a document that appointed someone as a representative using the Representation Agreement Act, or
  • a person can be appointed by the Court using the Patients Property Act,
  • a person could have been appointed either the Minister of Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development or by the Court using the Indian Act

templateElements.name: spouseNomineeFormalYesExplanation
templateElements.title:
The Public Guardian and Trustee (PGT) will need a copy of the legal document that proves that {panel.spouseNomineeName} was formally appointed as {panel.spouseName}'s `nominee`.

You can get a head start by asking {panel.spouseNomineeName} for that document now, or, you can wait for this service to remind you in a later step.

This service will tell you how to let them know in a later step.

templateElements.name: spouseDied5DaysAfterFAQ1
templateElements.title: Why does this date matter?
templateElements.body:
Under the law, in order for {panel.spouseName} to qualify for {deceasedName}'s `assets`, {panel.spouseName} must have lived for at least 5 days after {deceasedName} died. Once {panel.spouseName} has qualified, it doesn't matter if {panel.spouseName} is now dead.

The people managing {panel.spouseName}'s belongings need to know that you are applying for a `Representation Grant` for {deceasedName}.

For more information, click here for the Five-day survival rule from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA). (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: spouseCompletedFAQ1
elements.title: How can someone have more than 1 spouse?
elements.body:
Someone can have more than 1 `spouse` depending on the laws where they live.

Under B.C. law, if a person is legally married and they separate from their spouse but do not get a divorce, the person they separated from is still considered their spouse. If that same person then starts a new marriage-like relationship with a new partner, this new partner could be considered a spouse.

In this situation, the person could have 2 spouses because they didn't divorce their first spouse.

For more information, click here to read about who should be included as {deceasedName}'s spouse from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA). (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: spouseCompletedNoError
elements.title:
Please identify everyone who may be considered {deceasedName}'s `spouse` at the time {deceasedName} died. They should know that you are applying for a `Representation Grant` for {deceasedName}.

You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case the Court decides that this person should be considered {deceasedName}'s spouse.

Just because you are giving this person notice, it may not mean that they get part of {deceasedName}'s `estate`.

For more information, click here to read about who should be included as {deceasedName}'s spouse from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA). (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: childExists0
elements.title: Did {deceasedName} have any children when they died?

elements.name: childExistsFAQ1
elements.title: Do I include {deceasedName}'s legally adopted children?
elements.body:
Yes, you must include {deceasedName}'s legally adopted children. All of {deceasedName}'s biological and legally adopted children need to know that you are apply for a `Representation Grant`.

If you are not sure if a person was legally adopted by {deceasedName} or not, it is safer for you to include this person. You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case this person was legally adopted by {deceasedName}.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a Representation Grant, they don't automatically get part of {deceasedName}'s `estate`.

elements.name: childExistsFAQ1Reference
elements.title: FAQ1 Visual Reference
elements.body:

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a Representation Grant, they don't automatically get part of {deceasedName}'s `estate`.

elements.name: childExistsFAQ2
elements.title: Do I include {deceasedName}'s step-children?
elements.body:
No, you do not need to include {deceasedName}'s step-children because {deceasedName} did not legally adopt them. Only {deceasedName}'s biological or legally adopted children need to know that you are apply for a `Representation Grant`.

If you are not sure if a person was legally adopted by {deceasedName} or not, it is safer for you to include this person. You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case this personal was legally adopted by {deceasedName}.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a Representation Grant, they don't automatically get part of {deceasedName}'s `estate`.

If you are not sure if a person was legally adopted by {deceasedName} or not, it is safer for you to include this person. You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case this personal was legally adopted by {deceasedName}.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a Representation Grant, they don't automatically get part of {deceasedName}'s `estate`.

elements.name: childExistsFAQ3
elements.title: Do I include {deceasedName}'s children (biological or legally adopted) that were legally adopted by someone else?
elements.body:
The answer depends if {deceasedName} was alive when someone else legally adopted their children, and, if {deceasedName} gave up their parenting rights or not.

If {deceasedName} was alive at the time someone else legally adopted {deceasedName}'s children, and {deceasedName} gave up their parenting rights, {deceasedName}'s former children DO NOT need to be included.

If {deceasedName} had already died when {deceasedName}'s children were legally adopted by someone else, these children DO need to be included.

If {deceasedName} was alive when {deceasedName}'s children were legally adopted by someone else, but {deceasedName} did not give up their parenting rights, these children DO need to be included.

This last situation may happen if the children's other parent(s) gave up their parenting rights but {deceasedName} still kept their parenting rights.

If you are not sure if someone who has been adopted is still considered {deceasedName}'s child or not, it is safer for you to include this person. You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case the Court considers this person {deceasedName}'s child.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a `Representation Grant`, if they are not {deceasedName}'s child anymore, they don't automatically get part of {deceasedName}'s `estate`.

For more information, click here to read about who should be included as {deceasedName}'s children, if they were adopt, from the Adoption Act. (This link opens in a new tab)

templateElements.name: question253
templateElements.title: Rule 25-2 (8) - If person to whom notice is to be delivered is a minor
templateElements.body:
Rule 25-2 (8) - If person to whom notice is to be delivered is a minor
(8) If a person to whom documents are to be delivered under subrule (1) is a minor, the intended applicant must deliver those documents
- (a) as follows:
---   (i) if the applicant knows that the minor resides with all of the minor's parents, to those parents;
---  (ii) if subparagraph (i) does not apply but the applicant knows that a parent or guardian has responsibility for financial decisions relating to the minor, to that parent or guardian;
---   (iii) if neither subparagraph (i) nor subparagraph (ii) applies but the applicant knows of one or more addresses at which the minor resides, to the minor at each of those addresses, and
- (b) subject to subrule (9), to the Public Guardian and Trustee.

templateElements.name: question269
templateElements.title: Rule 25-2 (9) - If testamentary trust exists
templateElements.body:
Rule 25-2 (9) - If testamentary trust exists
(9) An intended applicant need not deliver documents under subrule (8) (b) to the Public Guardian and Trustee if
- (a) the intended applicant is an executor or alternate executor of the deceased's estate,
- (b) the minor is not a spouse or child of the deceased, and
- (c) the deceased's will:
---   (i) creates a trust for the interest of the minor in the estate, and
---   (ii) appoints a trustee for that trust.

templateElements.name: question263
templateElements.title: Rule 25-2 (10) and (11)
templateElements.body:
If person to whom notice is to be delivered is a mentally incompetent person
(10) Subrule (11) applies if
- (a) there has been appointed for a person to whom documents are to be delivered under subrule (1)
--- (i) a committee appointed under the Patients Property Act, or
--- (ii) the equivalent of a committee appointed by a court outside British Columbia, or
- (b) a person to whom documents are to be delivered under subrule (1) is or may be mentally incompetent and paragraph (a) of this subrule does not apply to the person.

How notice may be delivered to a mentally incompetent person
(11) If subrule (10) applies to a person to whom documents are to be delivered under subrule (1), the intended applicant must deliver the documents to the person as follows:
- (a) if subrule (10) (a) (i) applies, by delivering the documents to
--- (i) the committee referred to in that subparagraph, and
--- (ii) the Public Guardian and Trustee;
- (b) if subrule (10) (a) (ii) applies, by delivering the documents to
--- (i) the equivalent person referred to in that subparagraph, and
--- (ii) the Public Guardian and Trustee;
- (c) if subrule (10) (b) applies, by delivering the documents to the Public Guardian and Trustee in addition to delivering those documents to the person.

templateElements.name: childNomineeName

templateElements.description: This name should be written using the Roman alphabet. English and French are examples of languages that use the Roman alphabet.

templateElements.name: childNomineeFormal
templateElements.title: Was {panel.childNomineeName} formally appointed to help {panel.childName} manage their money and legal decisions?
templateElements.description:
These are the ways someone can be formally appointed.
  • {panel.childName} could have signed a document that gave someone else the power of attorney using the Power of Attorney Act,
  • {panel.childName} could have signed a document that appointed someone as a representative using the Representation Agreement Act, or
  • a person can be appointed by the Court using the Patients Property Act,
  • a person could have been appointed either the Minister of Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development or by the Court using the Indian Act

templateElements.name: childNomineeFormalYesExplanation
templateElements.title:
The Public Guardian and Trustee (PGT) will need a copy of the legal document that proves that {panel.childNomineeName} was formally appointed as {panel.childName}'s `nominee`.

You can get a head start by asking {panel.childNomineeName} for that document now, or, you can wait for this service to remind you in a later step.

templateElements.name: childNomineeFormalNoExplanation
templateElements.title:
Even if {panel.childNomineeName} was not formally appointed to help {panel.childName}, it is still best to let both {panel.childNomineeName} and {panel.childName} know that you are applying for a `Representation Grant`.

This service will tell you how to let them know in a later step.

templateElements.name: childDied5DaysAfter
templateElements.title: Did {panel.childName} die after {deceasedDateOfDeathPlus4}?

templateElements.name: childDied5DaysAfterFAQ1
templateElements.title: Why does this date matter?
templateElements.body:
Under the law, in order for {panel.childName} to qualify for {deceasedName}'s `assets`, {panel.childName} must have lived for at least 5 days after {deceasedName} died. Once {panel.childName} has qualified, it doesn't matter if {panel.childName} is now dead.

The people managing {panel.childName}'s belongings need to know that you are applying for a `Representation Grant` for {deceasedName}.

For more information, click here for the Five-day survival rule from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA). (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.title:
Please identify everyone who may be considered {deceasedName}'s child at the time {deceasedName} died. {deceasedName}'s children should know that you are applying for a `Representation Grant` for {deceasedName}.

You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case the Court decides that a person you've left out should be considered {deceasedName}'s child.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a Representation Grant, if they are not {deceasedName}'s child anymore, they don't automatically get part of {deceasedName}'s `estate`.

For more information, click here to read about who should be included as {deceasedName}'s child from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA). (This link opens in a new tab)

[Will version - custom intros GP, AWW, AGP, AGAWW, Resealing]
According the information you provided so far, your type of application is called X. Will dated. Y.

Let's first review the notice form that was filled out based on the information you provided. This notice form needs to be delivered (served) to the people and organizations you identified earlier (e.g. relatives, creditors).

When you submit your application for a representation grant, the court will need to know who you notified, and the people who delivered those notices.

We'll help you keep track and make sure you haven't missed anyone.

As part of the process to get a representation grant, you need to let the appropriate people know about your application. This means you need to deliver (serve) the following notice form to them.

People you will notify will have a ?fair? change to disagree with your applications. This gives them a fair chance ... work in 21 days... before you can file your documents to the courthouse.

elements.name: question406
elements.title: What if I don't get a written response when sending a notice electronically?
elements.body:
Because it is easy for people to change their contact information (such as their e-mail address of fax number), a written response is required to ensure you were able to successfully deliver your notice.



If you don't receive a response, you will have to resend the documents by mail or deliver the document to them in person.

elements.name: question456

[Old Spreadsheet Notes copied here Nov 12 2020]
Giving notification to the Public Guardian and Trustee (PGT) Part of the process in getting a representation grant requires you to notify specific people that you are applying. If those people are under 19 years of age, or they are not mentally competent, you will also need to notify the Public Guardian and Trustee (PGT). The PGT charges a fee for their services. The required fees are detailed in their list of fees (section for Wills, Estates and Succession Act, item (d)). http://www.trustee.bc.ca/fees/Documents/PGT%20Fee%20Schedule.pdf

elements.name: question402
elements.title: I got a Notice of Dispute after I delivered my notice.
elements.body:
What happens now?
After you deliver the notice to the appropriate people and organizations, there may be some who have concerns about your application and submit a Notice of Dispute (P29). In this situation, you will not be able to get an estate grant. You may want to talk things through with the person who submitted the Notice of Dispute and see if they are willing to withdraw it. You can also apply to remove the Notice of Dispute if you believe the reason for the dispute is not valid.

Old Sidebar FAQ What if I don't know all the assets in the deceased's estate? It is your responsibility to make sure you find and report all the deceased's assets that you know about. If you successfully become the deceased's personal representative and you find more assets to report afterwards, there will be additional forms to complete. Use either form P14 or P15 to tell the court. https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/justice/courthouse-services/documents-forms-records/court-forms/probate-forms

elements.name: landIntroExplanation
elements.title:
[add links??]
The next step is to identify all of the `assets` that you will manage as {deceasedName}'s `Personal Representative`.

This service will start by asking if {deceasedName} owned any land or buildings.

If {deceasedName} owned any land or buildings in British Columbia, make sure you have documents (such as a State of Title Certificate) from the BC Land Title & Survey Authority to answer the questions.

elements.name: landExists
elements.title: Did {deceasedName} own any land or buildings when they died?
elements.description: For example: House, Apartment, Condominium, Farm, etc.

elements.name: landExistsFAQ1
elements.title: Do I include a manufactured home (also know as a mobile home or a trailer)?
elements.body:
[TBD - update ref to Personal Item step]
No, do not include a manufactured home, a mobile home or a trailer as part of this question.

Manufactured homes are not registered with BC Land Title & Survey.

Include any manufactured homes in a future step for Personal Items.

elements.name: landExistsFAQ2
elements.title: Do I include land or a building that is specifically mentioned in {deceasedName}'s `Will` that {deceasedName} didn't own anymore when they died?
elements.body:
[visible if there is a Will only]
Yes, you do need to include any land or buildings that are specifically mentioned in {deceasedName}'s `Will`.

This service will ask if the land or building was still owned by {deceasedName} when they died.

Understanding land title certificates
A land title certificate contains a lot of information about a real estate. Here are some of the areas you may find useful for completing the questions. Registered Owner in Fee Simple Shows the owner(s) of the real estate. Taxation Authority
The one receiving property taxes on the real estate
Description of Land
Contains legal description about the real estate.
Charges, Liens and Interests
Lists any mortgages, liens or money owing on the property.

choices.text: Yes, I am satisfied that there was a diligent search for {deceasedName}'s Will and other testamentary documents.

elements.name: willSearchApplicantDiligentSearchConfirmedFAQ1
elements.title: What is a diligent search>
elements.body:
A diligent search is doing your best to check all the places where {deceasedName} usually kept their important documents. This means checking physical places as well electronic places.
  • Physical places include their home, safety deposit box, and their lawyer's office.
  • Electronic places include their smart phone, computer, external hard drive, and cloud storage.
If people are working together to apply for a `Representation Grant`, the `applicants` can decide which applicant searches which place.

There is also a document called a Search of Wills Notice. This document can help reveal the location of a will. You don't need to have gotten a Search of Wills Notice to answer "Yes" that you have done a diligent search.

This document is not necessary for your diligent search yes/no but it is eventually necessary. this service will complete it at a later point.
